conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to compare the average velocities of two cars, Car A and Car B, as they travel on a straight highway from t=0 to t1.
The graph shows their velocity-time relationships, where v1 is the initial velocity of Car A, and v2 is the initial velocity of Car B.
Identify the initial velocities of both cars. From the graph, Car A starts with a velocity v1 and Car B starts with a velocity v2.
Since both cars are traveling in the same direction, the average velocity of a car is given by the formula: Average velocity = (Final velocity - Initial velocity) / Time
Since the graph shows the velocity-time relationship, the final velocity for both cars will be the same at v2 at t1.

premise: Car A starts with a velocity v1 and ends with a velocity v2 at t1.
conclusion: Calculate the average velocity for Car A: Average velocity of Car A = (v2 - v1) / t1

premise: Car B starts with a velocity v2 and ends with a velocity v1 at t1.
conclusion: Calculate the average velocity for Car B: Average velocity of Car B = (v1 - v2) / t1

premise: The calculated average velocities for Car A and Car B are (v2 - v1) / t1 and (v1 - v2) / t1 respectively.
conclusion: Since both average velocities are equal, the average velocity of Car A and Car B are the same.

premise: During the time interval from t=0 to t1, the average velocity of both cars is calculated to be the same.
conclusion: The average velocity of both cars is the same during this time interval.
